body:
Yes, I understand findElement() returns null if it cannot find the element - but most here methods don't silently accept nulls as parameters, I believe.

In any case, sorry I don't see this bringing consistency - with this patch, if I do "findText(findElement(...))", it won't fail with NPE, but if I do "findElement(findElement(...), ...)" it will, I think. dtto for findSubElements, although I could see an argument about the inconsistency being fine for findSubElements.
Makes sense, thanks. This is a simple change to the README, merging it.

@blackleg thanks!  Let's see if this improves things.  In fact, there are a couple of other tests that occasionally fail on network errors that might benefit from this.  Possibly review and improve further after NB 11.2.

@jlahoda what is the current spec version?  I currently see same version in NB 11.2-beta2 as NB 11.1.  Just tried with clean userdir and disabling plugin centre first - I don't see nb-javac at all, although I do see JavaFX modules available ???  Enabling Java cluster fails when plugin centre disabled.  That doesn't sound right?!

Ok, I know now what is going on - the nb-javac modules are not part of the "3rdparty" cluster, and hence are not part of the source zip built by build-source-config (for cluster.config=release). And so they are not in the beta :-(. I didn't realize the cluster.properties need to change as well, and all is working for a build from the sources in git (as the modules are in the checkout). I apologize for that. 

I've submitted:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1556

to add the modules to the 3rdparty cluster, which should ensure they are part of the source distro.

For the record, the spec versions of these modules is "2.0".
Closing this one in favor of #1557
We could put these into rat exclusions, but the license info seemed better to me - these description files are under the Apache license, just cannot easily hold the license.
The JavaFX ones are excluded though. We should be consistent one way or another IMO.

Hi, we must go through ip clearance process.
The most paperwork are from donators 
 JetBrains s.r.o should transmit a software agreement https://www.apache.org/licenses/software-grant-template.pdf 
 It's important that each contributor (I hope the list is complete here: https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-netbeans/graphs/contributors) also have iCLA  
Workflow may be found over here.
https://www.apache.org/licenses/contributor-agreements.html

Then Apache NetBeans PMC have to vote for accepting code.

Then a lazy vote occurs on incubator list to ip clear.

Regards

> Hi, we must go through ip clearance process.
> The most paperwork are from donators
> JetBrains s.r.o should transmit a software agreement https://www.apache.org/licenses/software-grant-template.pdf
> It's important that each contributor (I hope the list is complete here: https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin-netbeans/graphs/contributors) also have iCLA

> 
> Then a lazy vote occurs on incubator list to ip clear.
> 
> Regards

Hi Eric, Ok, we will process your request and answer after some time.
Then please lets move the JavaFX ones to `licenseinfo.xml`. There is no real good reason not to state the license of the files. That way we don't need to discuss which license applies.
Please wait a little - Travis is still failing validly on this.

@jlahoda I noticed - just retriggered to see, although looked like it might be a valid issue - complaining about one of the nb-javac jars.  Don't worry, I merge nothing until it's green - just gives me headaches!
@neilcsmith-net your quicker, than I can write comments :-)

> I'm not very familiar with the clusters system--could you explain how to
> do this? Is this different from what I started with in the first version of
> this PR? For that version, @JaroslavTulach
> <https://github.com/JaroslavTulach> objected that new libraries were
> ending up in netbeans/platform/lib, which was undesirable. That included
> libraries that were previously already in the ide cluster (
> o.apache.commons.io and o.apache.commons.logging).
>
The cluster system actually dates back to Sun's architecture review
requirements - but it is a generally good idea.  The idea - driven by
requirements from Solaris - was that an application should only install ONE
copy of any shared libraries on a system; and Sun was building multiple
products on top of NetBeans.  So if there were two NetBeans-based
applications on a system, there should only be one copy of, say, the
platform modules or the editor modules, which both applications simply use
as "clusters" of libraries.  So the cluster system was invented - carve the
IDE and platform into chunks of relatied (and interdependent)
functionality, such that inter-cluster dependencies are unidirectional and
you - a directed graph.

In practice, in terms of people installing multiple copies of software on
systems, I don't think that is an enormous concern these days (this was
back in the era of thin-clients, so a "system" was likely big iron and the
"desktop" was a remote X connection).  But it forces us to think about both
macro-level dependencies - what functionality is and isn't related, what is
"essential" and what isn't, and what is "platform" vs. something else, and
factor things accordingly.  That keeps a clean definition of what is
"platform" and what isn't, and keeps the IDE and platform from merging into
a monolithic hairball (which it once, circa 1999, was).  So it's a good
thing to keep.

Now, re SVG icons, that seems to me to be something which obviously belongs
in the platform.  Display resolution is not going to go *down* and we are
past the point where raster formats for this sort of thing are inadequate;
mobile platforms typically have you create raster icons in multiple
resolutions, which is annoying and goes out of date with the next model;
and on the desktop, we're not dealing with standardized screen sizes and
resolutions, so the only sane way to deal that is a resolution-independent
graphics format.

So, this belongs in the platform, period.

If the objection is that the IDE itself is not yet using SVG icons, so it
will result in library dependencies getting packaged which nothing
uses, *that's
a build-system problem, not an architecture problem.*  Fix the build system
so the application-building phase detects that there are libraries which
are not referenced in the manifest of any module or other library, and
deletes those.  That's as simple as building a graph of inter-JAR
dependencies and then seeing if what you actually get is *more than one
distinct graph*, and deleting everything that is not in the largest graph
which is the actual application.

-Tim

@jlahoda can you clarify what being part of source build but not binary build means?  Concerned about us replicating a blocking issue that arose with JavaFX.

Out of interest, having looked at JavaFX files being in `external` rather than `release/modules/ext` is there a reason this one has to be done differently? Also, eg. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/extra/libs.javafx.linux/nbproject/project.properties#L23
Looks good!

Frankly, I am getting concerned as well. Maybe it is time to use the backup plan?

Overall, what I don't like about the way JavaFX is handled is that if I do a build from source, the JavaFX modules are installed already. (These are in the extra cluster, which is I hope not packed in the binary distro, but still.) Not sure if that's technically OK for JavaFX, but I can understand why Jaroslav prefers that for JavaFX - some stuff simply does not work without it. But for javac, I'd *really* prefer if it wasn't installed "automatically". I think users should be given a realistic chance to use the javac from JDK, even if they build from source.

Part of this is that build of e.g. extra/nbjavac.api will not download the nb-javac binary - the intent is to only create an NBM that will download the binary when installed.

So, we have a source distro, which includes the 3rdparty cluster, and the nbjavac modules must be part of that in order for them to be part of the distro. But building the source distro will build the 3rdparty cluster as well, and so would include the nbjavac modules, and I think it is preferred to not do that (because we would need to install the external nb-javac library for this to work correctly). So I tried to disable that build, although I agree that's ugly. I would prefer some cleaner solution, but I suspect that will take time (esp. if we try to include JavaFX as well). One possibility that comes to mind (and probably cleaner) would be to not put the nbjavac modules into the extra cluster, but rather embed them directly in some module (like nb/updatecenters itself). But I'd need to thing about that and discuss further.

Regarding external+mapping in properties vs. release - there is no reason why it would have to be done this way, but using release is cleaner (and works for all ant NetBeans projects, while the mapping in properties only works inside the main repo, AFAIK )

What was the blocking issue with JavaFX?

Seems that trying to layer up workarounds to make things for sanely for modules in extra/3rdparty cluster will not work. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1560 strives to solve the issues in a different way.
I cannot check all parameters, but I guess a package refactory to org.apache.netbeans (or org.netbeans) will also be needed.
If this works and Neil approves, I approve. Thanks for the hard work on this issue.

I have to say I'd prefer the previous approach, and copying JavaFX approach for NB 11.2 given we're meant to be finalising last beta, with view to improving that in master after release?  I also have a concern that this has failed all Travis tests at the moment - will retrigger them now and see if it's a glitch.

@jlahoda totally understand your problem over the JavaFX approach.  That they get included when doing a straight build of the source is an annoyance here too.  We need some options to disable that - causes issues in testing releases as well.

However, the binary builds as done on the build server do not include the extra cluster at all.  The binary build is Apache compliant AFAIK.  And JavaFX must be explicitly enabled.  What we need to also do is document better how an end user can build that compliant binary locally.

However, for NB 11.2 I'd prefer we copy the JavaFX approach fully and then seek to address the above issues as soon as master reopens for 11.3?  Or revert and switch back to plan B and a temporary update centre?

I can't remember the exact issues with the JavaFX support.  @matthiasblaesing probably knows better.  I think we initially thought the binaries were being included in places they shouldn't, but was actually more to do with licenses showing up where they shouldn't?
Travis failures seem consistent.
It will not hurt not having it in release package. It's more to have nice apidoc website. And will try to port it to the previous release later.
If okay I can extend this PR by adding inline hint feature for variables, too.

For the build failure - this is the relevant part of the log:

```
BUILD FAILED
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/nbbuild/build.xml:1278: The following error occurred while executing this line:
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/nb/updatecenters/build.xml:105: The following error occurred while executing this line:
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/nb/updatecenters/extras/build.xml:24: The following error occurred while executing this line:
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/nb/updatecenters/extras/nbproject/build-impl.xml:62: Cannot find NetBeans build harness. 
Check that nbplatform.default.netbeans.dest.dir and nbplatform.default.harness.dir are defined. 
On a developer machine these are normally defined in ${user.properties.file}=${netbeans.user}/build.properties 
but for automated builds you should pass these properties to Ant explicitly. 
You may instead download the harness and platform: -Dbootstrap.url=.../tasks.jar -Dautoupdate.catalog.url=.../updates.xml
```

Indeed this is locally reproducible, by running `ant clean` after a successful prior build.

> I can't remember the exact issues with the JavaFX support. @matthiasblaesing probably knows better. I think we initially thought the binaries were being included in places they shouldn't, but was actually more to do with licenses showing up where they shouldn't?

You are right. The binaries from the extra cluster were picked up and their license (GPLv2-CPE) was included in the LICENSE file although they were not included in the final zip. That is the benefit of #1560, as the binaries are never present at build time, we don't need a hack to exclude them.

I have a question. What does `NP-38` mean? Issue number for Payara support? Payara support was already donated to Apache NetBeans, wasn't it? If so, I think we should use the issue number of JIRA for NetBeans. i.e. https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/NETBEANS/issues

Hi @junichi11,

Yes NP-38 is an internal Jira ticket id that is used internally in Payara Ecosystem projects & helps in Sprint planning.

@graben was trying to find time to look at enhancing similarly - been mentioned various times by users.  While I somewhat understand @sharpedavid comment, maybe there's a way to make it configurable?  Also would be great to cover parameters that are method return values.

One area that would be good to drop duplication though is on varargs.  Wonder how easy to just label the first?

I would prefer using the approach with less changes from a release point of view, even if we revise afterwards, but will leave decision up to @jlahoda what you'd prefer in 11.2?

However, @matthiasblaesing not sure what you mean by more reproducible for end users?  Or zipping the netbeans file?  `ant build` will give a NetBeans zip that does not include the extras cluster.  We should probably rewrite the instructions at http://netbeans.apache.org/download/dev/index.html to specify `ant build` and not to use the `nbbuild/netbeans` folder.  There are other differences from the released binaries.

We could probably fix up `ant tryme` to not use extras by default - remove from the clusters file and pass as an optional extra cluster to the launcher via ant?

Just copy the "specific" code (DRAFT :)) from visitliteral to visitidentifier and visitmethodinvokation does make the feature work for variables and methods return, too. I do not see any performance issues at the moment.

> > It seems this patch only affect literals? Shouldn't it fire for every kind of parameter? Maybe configurable for performance reasons? :)
> 
> I bet the thought is that if you're passing in an actual variable, you should just a good variable name. Otherwise you have lots of instances of:
> 
> `firstName.substring(beginIndex: beginIndex, endIndex: endIndex);`

It's just a simple if around the put of the hint :)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1685573/66561349-9b33f100-eb59-11e9-9eef-dee1b509aaee.png)

@jGauravGupta Thank you for your answer :)
I'm not sure whether that's OK. Could you please ask via the mailing list about using an issue id of another JIRA without issue id of NetBeans JIRA on commit messages?

I'm worried about the following:
- Payara modules are already in NetBeans repo.
- Other developers can't understand what that number means.
- Payara team can look at the issue, but other than those people can't do it.
- After another module(e.g. MyModule) is donated in the future, if the author uses the issue number(e.g. [MYMODULE-55]) of another bug tracker, maybe it would be the cause of confusing.
I was actually working on replicating what JavaFX is doing, but I currently ended up with a license file that includes GPL, and didn't have time to try to solve that.

@jlahoda the code that excludes the extra cluster from license can be seen here: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1143/files

@neilcsmith-net What I meant to say above is, that if the "netbeans" folder of a local build is closer to the zip we distribute, the final distributed structure is more thoroughly tested. The local build of netbeans currently includes the OpenJFX libraries and does not install them. This does not replicated the experience of an end user.

@matthiasblaesing had literally just hunted out the same link :smile:  Although from looking at it I'd have assumed no issue.

So, the changes I said above would address that issue with the `netbeans` folder by excluding the extra cluster by default from `ant tryme`.  And IMO we shouldn't be telling people to test by running `nbbuild/netbeans/bin/netbeans` but either `ant tryme` or `ant build` anyway?

> And IMO we shouldn't be telling people to test by running `nbbuild/netbeans/bin/netbeans` but either `ant tryme` or `ant build` anyway?

Yes, but in this case **I'm** "the user" (with all negative connotations :smiley:)

@matthiasblaesing I'm sure we can change even your habits! :wink:

EDIT : and anyway, if we remove it from the default clusters, you'd have to opt in to have extras anyway, so you'd get what you want?
I also had some troubles, that not always shows the inline hint. Will show an example later by reprodcution.

I've pushed an update to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1556, which (if it passes Travis) uses the same approach as JavaFX for nb-javac. Had to do changes to the filtering, because otherwise CreateLicenseSummary was picking up the javac jars from libs.javacapi/libs.javacimpl (which are not part of the distribution, and are not part of the netbeans directory), and mixing them with the jars in the extra cluster.

But, to me, that is at most for 11.2 - to me, it feels like we are adding workaround for something that should not need workarounds. The approach in this PR is much saner, IMO.

As for excluding the extra cluster from ant tryme, etc. - traditionally, many (experimental, prototype, unstable, etc.) modules were compiled in the extra cluster. We don't have any like that right now, but closing the door to have them does not sound necessary. Not having a "3rdparty" cluster (mapped to "extra" folder) that is half in the distro and half isn't sounds like a much better direction.

And I think I agree with Matthias that the closer the outcome of running "ant"  is to running "ant build-source-config && <unpack> && ant build && <unzip>", the better. After all, the issue here is that I have tested the result of "ant", not the result of the build after the full loop.

> And I think I agree with Matthias that the closer the outcome of running "ant" is to running "ant build-source-config && && ant build && ", the better. After all, the issue here is that I have tested the result of "ant", not the result of the build after the full loop.

We're all in agreement there, but something for post 11.2.  I'm kind of neutral on approach - pros and cons to both, and possible to make either work, but lot of sense to what you're saying here.

I understand the history of the extra cluster, and it does make sense to separate.  But, whatever happens with this it would still be good to make it opt-in so anything in it isn't run (or built?) by default.  I'm not saying close the door to it - I'm suggesting making `ant tryme` and running the built zip more equivalent.

And from an end-user perspective, I'd prefer `ant` was at least equivalent to `ant build` and we stopped telling people that the main build output is `nbbuild/netbeans` as opposed to the `NetBeans-***-zip` - even if content except for extra isn't that different.

@jlahoda thanks!  I see two test failures.  First is with RAT - think license-info files have wrong links for the jar.external files now?!  Second is ergonomics - will retrigger to make sure it's related - have seen that fail without cause a few times.

I believe this change may have broke importing options since it tries to parse the build number.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-3198

> -it is better to check for Tree (and Element and TypeMirror) types using getKind() == Kind., as is done in the existing test. The API does not guarantee that an AST node that is instanceof MethodInvocationTree will actually model a method invocation - a single implementation class may implement any number of the AST interfaces, and select its nature using getKind().

Well, I have to cast to specific class so testing with instanceof seams necessary to me. I can also check the kind but I don't think it will worth it?!

@neilcsmith-net I saw that it should be coming from MainImpl.java. Is it from the ide branding module?

The null is because it is expecting a date for the regex, e.g. 20190924, but we now use the git hash.

Fixed my links above. 

@oyarzun which regex?

I debugged and the build number is correctly exported (not-null). The regexp @oyarzun references is this:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/options.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsExportModel.java#L99

It is used here:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/options.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsExportModel.java#L218

And the reason for the null value is here:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/options.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsExportModel.java#L229

TL;DR: The module assumes, that the build number always contains a date pattern.

This is even tested:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/options.api/test/unit/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsExportModelTest.java#L345
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/options.api/test/unit/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsExportModelTest.java#L362

@matthiasblaesing thanks, yes just found the regex but not tests. Fun debugging via GitHub UI on a phone! :smile:

OK, so build number is never going to have a build date in it going forward! So, we'll need to decide a quick fix for 11.2 and a better one for 11.3.

Doing e.g. "tree instanceof MethodInvocationTree" is not required in the trees API. If "tree.getKind() == Kind.METHOD_INVOCATION", then the tree can be cast to MethodInvocationTree, otherwise, it should not be cast, even if it the cast itself might pass.

The instanceof ensures the instance in the "tree" variable can be cast to MethodInvocationTree, but it does not ensure the actual instance models the method invocation node, because the actual instance may be of e.g. type:
class X implements MethodInvocationTree, NewClassTree, ... {}

I.e. the actual implementation classes may implement any number of the API interfaces, so instanceof is unreliable. Tree.getKind() is the documented way to detect tree types.

I hope the rat/verify-libs-and-licenses problem might be gone in the last commit (and if not, that can be fixed, I think). But I am afraid I have no idea what's about the ergonomics failure. Likely another interaction with modules that are there, but should not?

IMHO it's unnecessary to check the kind at this moment. It's already checked in the if before. The only thing done is casting to a specific class (MethodInvocationTree or NewClassTree) and calling a method declared in those two interfaces. The check and cast is only needed to ensure runtime and compile time safety. Even if the current implementation of the tree will implement something crude like class X implements MethodInvocationTree, NewClassTree the code ensures that only the right kind of tree will reach this line of code and it can syntactically call getArguments() method.

Could we, as a quick fix, return a hardcoded date here, e.g., the date of beta3 for 11.2 beta3 and, then the date of the final release when we have it:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/options.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsExportModel.java#L229

@geertjanw yes, that's exactly what I've got in mind to do on Monday if no-one suggests anything different. I'm not quite sure at the moment why this code wants the build date in the first place, but that should at least work as a quick fix.

EDIT : actually my plan is date of switch to hash. We can't code a different date between beta3 and release if we're aiming for binary identical.

For the "why is it there": 
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/1b56603318f657219d54311be763cfba42fb8618/platform/options.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/options/export/OptionsChooserPanel.java#L439-L445

Looks like feature detection to me. Using a fixed date should make it work.

Yes, strictly speaking, in this particular case, this would work. But I am not sure what's the problem in simply using getKind() instead of instanceof? To the best of my knowledge, that's what the API expects (and this is not a NetBeans API, so we cannot change the approach here, just adhere or not adhere to it here). I.e. the idiom in this API is to check the Kind, and then cast, no instanceof - why is it necessary to deviate from it here?

Well, as you already said it's not save how the tree is really implemented. So the kind could return another type th an the cast would. In such a case an exception would be the result by unsafe cast. That's why I would prefer the instanceof check to save the cast would not throw an exception.
But I can combine to ensure both. :blush:

Checking getKind() and then casting is generally a safe idiom for Trees, Elements and TypeMirrors. Using instanceof is generally not a safe idiom to use on these. There is some code in the IDE that was written before the API was redesigned this way, and these still use instanceof, but I was always hoping the use of instanceof on Tree would fade away over time, not increase.

(The instanceof works now only because both MethodInvocationTree and NewClassTree have getArguments() method, which is called in both braches. But if we ever need to call a different method in any of the branches, things may break. NewClassTree.getClassBody() looks like a possible candidate for a method that may need to be called at some point in one of the branches.)

@jlahoda : Did switch to check getKind instead of instanceof and enhance unit test. IMHO next should be to move code to its own method and also add to visitidentifier and visitmethodinvokation to make feature available for variables and method returns, too.
@JaroslavTulach we are in feature freeze, merges to master should have be cleared with @neilcsmith-net before merging.
I am still not sure what's the problem in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1556 - but this patch IMO leads to less workarounds on various places, so while bigger, feels safer to me.
Opps. I haven't realized that. Sorry, feel free to backout and I'll be more careful next time.
@jlahoda can this pull request be merge before #1556
vote is ok.

@JaroslavTulach no problem!  This looks like it's probably safe enough to leave in.

Out of interest, should we be considering using the `release` attribute as well in some of these?

Thanks @jlahoda So, let's go with this and close #1556.  However, this will also break #1547 I think?  Do you want to integrate the changes from that into this before I merge?

Later, once NB 11.3 window opens be good to bring JavaFX to match this as @matthiasblaesing suggested.  It would also be good if we can find a way to make this optional so that someone can instead choose to build from source and get the plugins pre-installed - no reason a downstream user, distribution or project need be hampered by the same restrictions we are with binaries (see recent user@ education question).
Closing in favour of #1560
@Akshay-Gupta-Oracle #1556 has been closed in favour of #1560 Perhaps coordinate there with @jlahoda to make sure that fix includes these changes?
Would it make sense to merge 1547, I would then merge master here and then we could merge this? Should be only a few hours for me for the rebase.
If intended for 11.2(?), please add milestone and add me as reviewer when ready.  That added if statement probably needs formatting and braces too?
Up to you - your changes here move those files I think, so wasn't sure of consequences of that.  Happy for you to handle merging both to master as best works for you.

@Akshay-Gupta-Oracle Please use `[NETBEANS-XXXX]`(e.g. `[NETBEANS-3202]`) instead of `[Netbeans:3202]` because the link of this PR is added to the JIRA.

If the icons are derived from the ALv2 licensed icon from gradle, then please also check if there is a NOTICE file we have to carry on (the licenseinfo.xml needs to be updated with that info). The same rules as for all NOTICE files also apply here: The info should be as short as legally possible.
I think it would also be good to say in the comment where the icons come from/derive from, which might make it easier to update/relicense in the future.

Dear @matthiasblaesing could you guide me in this? Please check the licenseinfo.xml-s in this PR. I hope I've updated the well. But I have no idea at the moment how the final NOTICE file is being generated other than is is some concatenation of the external libraries license informations.

For the NOTICE part: Apache License [Paragraph 4d](https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0#redistribution) requires attributes to be merged into a NOTICE file. Projects outside the ASF are not required to carry a NOTICE file, but if their dependencies use one, this is contagious. The ASF requires all projects to carry a NOTICE file and we merge our bare-bone file with the individual NOTICES from our dependencies.

This also applies to individual files. See here for a sample:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/f5184a5be7b7605033c23196f72403b17f851d9c/platform/o.n.swing.plaf/licenseinfo.xml#L47-L57

I checked the NOTICE file for gradle, found here:
https://gradle.org/next-steps/?version=5.6.2&format=bin
https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/subprojects/distributions/src/toplevel/NOTICE

For the icons I see nothing that is relevant in the notice file.

A comment (either a real XML comment (will be ignored by processing) or a comment entry would be helpful to clear the source/base of the icons). Something along the lines:

```xml
    <fileset>
        <file>src/org/netbeans/modules/gradle/java/resources/javaseProjectIcon.png</file>
        <file>src/org/netbeans/modules/gradle/java/resources/javaseProjectIcon_dark.png</file>
        <license ref="Apache-2.0" />
        <comment type="COMMENT_UNSUPPORTED">
        Icons are based based on artwork distributed with Gradle (ALv2 licensed)
        </comment>
    </fileset>
```

Or an URL/description how the base artwork was retrieved.

Thank you @borisheithecker. Please just add a new commit to the branch you used to create the PR and it will become part of the PR.

@juneau001 I have better experience with using rebasing patches, instead of merging the base  branch into the feature branch as done here. For me the rebasing leads to a history, that can be much easier be refactored/cleaned up.

I've added a test case, please have a look at it. However, to be honest, I
don't think a unit test makes much sense with this kind of issue.
The problem is that the JUnit test case classes are loaded with the regular
JDK classloaders. JUnit doesn't use the NetBeans class loader system.
Tweaking a ProxyClassLoader into loading the test package-info plus test
annotation (that's what I did) doesn't really make much sense unless you'd
change more code in ProxyClassLoader (creating overridable methods) only
for the sake of testing, or you'd have to find a way to prevent JUnit from
loading a designated package into its classloader at startup.
Boris
